captions.text:
You do have a name ?
My name is gladiator.

How dare you
show your back to me ?
[ crowd murmuring ]

You will remove your helmet
and tell me your name.

My name is
maximus decimus meridius,

Loyal servant to the true
emperor, marcus aurelius,

And I will have my vengeance...
In this life or the next.

[ chanting ]
live !  Live !  Live !
Live !  Live !  Live !

Live !  Live !  Live !
Live !  Live !  Live !

title: Gladiator (5/8) Movie CLIP - My Name is Maximus (2000) HD

comments.text:
He is a bi***. When his father, Marcus Aurelius died of illness after 
conquering some Gaul territories and the continuation of his campaign, 
Commodus did not continue his father's ambition, and simply left for the 
good life of Rome. But in the movie, it is portrayed that Commodus murdered 
Marcus Aurelius.

comments.author: OhMyBooda

comments.text:
I wonder if the acoustics in the Coliseum were like that in real life? Like 
could the crowd hear the voices of people who were out in the middle of the 
ground? Or was that just done for the movie?﻿
comments.author: Kyle Blank

comments.text:
By most accounts, yes, it was designed so someone speaking could be heard 
by all. In addition the orientation of the Flavian Ampetheater was canted a 
few degrees so that the person sitting in the seat of honor would never 
have the sun in their eyes. They knew what they were doing.
comments.author: 8UP1977

comments.text:
I believe it was this same Coliseum on a documentary I watched that said 
the Coliseum could be flooded with water where they could float boats and 
put on real mock battles for the crowds to watch.  If this was the same 
place, it had a whole water system built underneath, really amazing.
comments.author: Deborah L C

comments.text:
+turboplazz It could cram about 50-80k people.  It didn't seem that big 
when I was there, but much of it has deteriorated over the years.  It's 
only half of what it used to be.  The closest NFL stadium today that 
resembles the Colosseum is Qualcomm (home of the Chargers)--to me anyways.
comments.author: canibus19

comments.text:
+Kyle Blank If you ever visit Rome you will actually be shocked at the size 
of the Coliseum. I was. It is the size of a major football arena in todays 
time. It is not tiny by any means
comments.author: turboplazz

comments.text:
Coolbeans, good to know. The Coliseum in reality also wasn't as large as 
they portrayed it in the film. They portrayed it larger in the film because 
Ridley Scott felt that accurately portrayed, it would have seemed too small 
for the audience.
comments.author: Kyle Blank

comments.text:
If memory serves me correctly, its supposed to be like two Greek 
amphitheaters if memory serves correctly for more space and similar 
acoustics.
